image.altText: Graph depicting sea ice melting.

items.synopsis: Scientists say warming ocean temperatures are having an alarming impact on Antarctic sea ice levels, with currently 1.5 million square kilometres less sea ice than is typical at this time.

title.children: Sea ice freezes and melts with the seasons. But this year, it's looking a bit different

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's unemployment rate has remained at 3.7 per cent for August, with employment increasing by 65,000 people and unemployment dropping slightly. Business reporters Emily Stewart and Rachel Pupazzoni are running the markets blog today with all the latest business news. Follow live here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Unemployment rate remains at 3.7 per cent for August

featuredLink.title: Live: Local shares open slightly higher, August jobs data to come, Myer profits up 23pc

children.content: Australia's unemployment rate has remained at 3.7 per cent for August, with employment increasing by 65,000 people and unemployment dropping slightly.
Business reporters Emily Stewart and Rachel Pupazzoni are running the markets blog today with all the latest business news.
Follow live here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Queensland Police have charged a man with trafficking dangerous drugs after he allegedly sold heroin in the Darra area, in south-west Brisbane. Police executed a search warrant at a Darra house and linked restaurant where they allege they located a quantity of dangerous drugs. Police also recovered over $1 million worth of alleged stolen property including tools, high-end designer fashion clothing and accessories, electrical goods, alcohol, firearms and a substantial sum of cash. A 61-year-old Darra man faces a number of charges including one count of drug trafficking. He will reappear in the Richland Magistrates Court on November 8. It is alleged that some customers were paying for drugs with stolen property which were then on-sold to the community through local markets. Investigations are ongoing including identifying owners of the stolen property.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Police claim stolen goods sold onto markets recovered in alleged drug trafficking scheme

children.content: Queensland Police have charged a man with trafficking dangerous drugs after he

in south-west Brisbane.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Toxicology reports have confirmed a Queensland man who died of a suspected snakebite did not have any venom in his system. Donny Morrison was attending the 100th anniversary of the Koumala State School, south of Mackay, on Saturday evening when another man had a brown snake wrapped around his leg. The 68-year-old grandfather was struck multiple times in the chest and arms as he removed the snake and took it away from others at the celebration. More details here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Snakebite ruled out as cause of grandfather's death by coroner

featuredLink.title: Snakebite ruled out as cause of death of beloved grandfather as coroner finds no venom in system

children.content: Toxicology reports have confirmed a Queensland man who died of a suspected snakebite

Donny Morrison was attending the 100th anniversary of the Koumala State School, south of Mackay, on Saturday evening when
another man had a brown snake wrapped around his leg
The 68-year-old grandfather
was struck multiple times
in the chest and arms as he removed the snake and took it away from others at the celebration.
More details here:

title.children: Unemployment rate steady at 3.7pc, Myer profits up 23pc, local shares open slightly higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Aussie dollar is up +0.2% to $US64.34 following news the unemployment rate remained steady in August at 3.7%. The All Ordinaries and ASX 200 are also up about +0.3 % (at 12.00pm AEST). BDO Economics Partner Anders Magnusson says a low unemployment rate usually indicates that things are good for households. "However, this is currently accompanied by high multiple job holdings and increasing hours worked per employee, which suggests otherwise. With costs rising more quickly than wages, Australians are working more jobs and longer hours to make ends meet." It all means there is unlikely to be further interest rate hikes from the Reserve Bank next month. Mr Magnusson says he expects inflation to continue decreasing. "Simultaneously low unemployment should be viewed by the RBA as a good thing rather than an inflation risk. Especially as wages have continued to grow by less than inflation over the last year."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Aussie dollar up after jobs data

children.content: The Aussie dollar is up +0.2% to $US64.34 following news the unemployment rate remained steady in August at 3.7%.
The All Ordinaries and ASX 200 are also up about +0.3 % (at 12.00pm AEST).
BDO Economics Partner Anders Magnusson says a low unemployment rate usually indicates that things are good for households.
"However, this is currently accompanied by high multiple job holdings and increasing hours worked per employee, which suggests otherwise.
With costs rising more quickly than wages, Australians are working more jobs and longer hours to make ends meet."
It all means there is
unlikely to be further interest rate hikes from the Reserve Bank next month
Mr Magnusson says he expects
inflation to continue decreasing.
"Simultaneously low unemployment should be viewed by the RBA as a good thing rather than an inflation risk.
Especially as wages have continued to grow by less than inflation over the last year."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The unemployment rate has remained steady at 3.7% in August. Employment has increased by 65,000 people and the number of unemployed people has dropped slightly, by around 3,000 people. ABS head of labour statistics, Bjorn Jarvis said the large increase in employment came after a small drop in July, during the school holiday period. "Looking over the past two months, the average employment growth was around 32,000 people per month, which is similar to the average growth over the past year." Hours worked fell 0.5% in August, however, it remains higher than the same time last year. "The strength in hours worked over the past year, relative to employment growth, shows the demand for labour is continuing to be met by people working mroe hours, to some extend," said Mr Jarvis.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 65,000 more employed people as unemployment rate stays steady

children.content: The unemployment rate has remained
steady at 3.7% in August.
Employment has increased by 65,000 people
and the number of
unemployed people has dropped slightly
, by around 3,000 people.
ABS head of labour statistics, Bjorn Jarvis said the large increase in employment came after a small drop in July, during the school holiday period.
"Looking over the past two months, the average employment growth was around 32,000 people per month, which is similar to the average growth over the past year."
Hours worked fell 0.5% in August, however, it remains higher than the same time last year.
"The strength in hours worked over the past year, relative to employment growth, shows the demand for labour is continuing to be met by people working mroe hours, to some extend," said Mr Jarvis.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's unemployment rate has remained steady at 3.7% for August. The Australian Bureau of Statistics Labour Force statistics show the participation rate has increased to 67%. We'll bring you more on what this means for the economy and interest rates shortly — stay with us.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Breaking news: unemployment rate steady

children.content: Australia's unemployment rate has remained steady at 3.7% for August.
The Australian Bureau of Statistics Labour Force statistics show the participation rate has increased to 67%.
We'll bring you more on what this means for the economy and interest rates shortly — stay with us.
